ruleset.name: Design
ruleset.description: The Design ruleset contains rules that flag suboptimal code implementations. Alternate approaches are suggested.

rule.name: UseUtilityClass
rule.message: All methods are static. Consider using a utility class instead. Alternatively, you could add a private constructor or make the class abstract to silence this warning.
rule.description: For classes that only have static methods, consider making them utility classes. Note that this doesn't apply to abstract classes, since their subclasses may well include non-static methods. Also, if you want this class to be a utility class, remember to add a private constructor to prevent instantiation. (Note, that this use was known before PMD 5.1.0 as UseSingleton).

rule.name: SimplifyBooleanReturns
rule.message: Avoid unnecessary if..then..else statements when returning booleans
rule.description: Avoid unnecessary if-then-else statements when returning a boolean. The result of the conditional test can be returned instead.

rule.name: SimplifyBooleanExpressions
rule.message: Avoid unnecessary comparisons in boolean expressions
rule.description: Avoid unnecessary comparisons in boolean expressions, they serve no purpose and impacts readability.

rule.name: SwitchStmtsShouldHaveDefault
rule.message: Switch statements should have a default label
rule.description: All switch statements should include a default option to catch any unspecified values.

rule.name: AvoidDeeplyNestedIfStmts
rule.message: Deeply nested if..then statements are hard to read
rule.description: Avoid creating deeply nested if-then statements since they are harder to read and error-prone to maintain.

rule.name: AvoidReassigningParameters
rule.message: Avoid reassigning parameters such as ''{0}''
rule.description: Reassigning values to incoming parameters is not recommended. Use temporary local variables instead.

rule.name: SwitchDensity
rule.message: A high ratio of statements to labels in a switch statement. Consider refactoring.
rule.description: A high ratio of statements to labels in a switch statement implies that the switch statement is overloaded. Consider moving the statements into new methods or creating subclasses based on the switch variable.

rule.name: ConstructorCallsOverridableMethod
rule.message: Overridable {0} called during object construction
rule.description: Calling overridable methods during construction poses a risk of invoking methods on an incompletely constructed object and can be difficult to debug. It may leave the sub-class unable to construct its superclass or forced to replicate the construction process completely within itself, losing the ability to call super(). If the default constructor contains a call to an overridable method, the subclass may be completely uninstantiable. Note that this includes method calls throughout the control flow graph - i.e., if a constructor Foo() calls a private method bar() that calls a public method buz(), this denotes a problem.

rule.name: AccessorClassGeneration
rule.message: Avoid instantiation through private constructors from outside of the constructor's class.
rule.description: Instantiation by way of private constructors from outside of the constructor's class often causes the generation of an accessor. A factory method, or non-privatization of the constructor can eliminate this situation. The generated class file is actually an interface. It gives the accessing class the ability to invoke a new hidden package scope constructor that takes the interface as a supplementary parameter. This turns a private constructor effectively into one with package scope, and is challenging to discern.

rule.name: FinalFieldCouldBeStatic
rule.message: This final field could be made static
rule.description: If a final field is assigned to a compile-time constant, it could be made static, thus saving overhead in each object at runtime.

rule.name: CloseResource
rule.message: Ensure that resources like this {0} object are closed after use
rule.description: Ensure that resources (like Connection, Statement, and ResultSet objects) are always closed after use.

rule.name: NonStaticInitializer
rule.message: Non-static initializers are confusing
rule.description: A non-static initializer block will be called any time a constructor is invoked (just prior to invoking the constructor). While this is a valid language construct, it is rarely used and is confusing.

rule.name: DefaultLabelNotLastInSwitchStmt
rule.message: The default label should be the last label in a switch statement
rule.description: By convention, the default label should be the last label in a switch statement.

rule.name: NonCaseLabelInSwitchStatement
rule.message: A non-case label was present in a switch statement
rule.description: A non-case label (e.g. a named break/continue label) was present in a switch statement. This legal, but confusing. It is easy to mix up the case labels and the non-case labels.

rule.name: OptimizableToArrayCall
rule.message: This call to Collection.toArray() may be optimizable
rule.description: Calls to a collection's toArray() method should specify target arrays sized to match the size of the collection. Initial arrays that are too small are discarded in favour of new ones that have to be created that are the proper size.

rule.name: BadComparison
rule.message: Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN
rule.description: Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN. Due to the implicit lack of representation precision when comparing floating point numbers these are likely to cause logic errors.
rule.example: boolean x = (y == Double.NaN);

rule.name: EqualsNull
rule.message: Avoid using equals() to compare against null
rule.description: Tests for null should not use the equals() method. The '==' operator should be used instead.

rule.name: ConfusingTernary
rule.message: Avoid if (x != y) ..; else ..;

rule.name: InstantiationToGetClass
rule.message: Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead
rule.description: Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead.

rule.name: IdempotentOperations
rule.message: Avoid idempotent operations (like assigning a variable to itself).
rule.description: Avoid idempotent operations - they have no effect.

rule.name: SimpleDateFormatNeedsLocale
rule.message: When instantiating a SimpleDateFormat object, specify a Locale
rule.description: Be sure to specify a Locale when creating SimpleDateFormat instances to ensure that locale-appropriate formatting is used.

rule.name: ImmutableField
rule.message: Private field ''{0}'' could be made final; it is only initialized in the declaration or constructor.
rule.description: Identifies private fields whose values never change once they are initialized either in the declaration of the field or by a constructor. This helps in converting existing classes to becoming immutable ones.

rule.name: UseLocaleWithCaseConversions
rule.message: When doing a String.toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() call, use a Locale
rule.description: When doing String.toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() conversions, use Locales to avoids problems with languages that have unusual conventions, i.e. Turkish.

rule.name: AvoidProtectedFieldInFinalClass
rule.message: Avoid protected fields in a final class. Change to private or package access.
rule.description: Do not use protected fields in final classes since they cannot be subclassed. Clarify your intent by using private or package access modifiers instead.

rule.name: AssignmentToNonFinalStatic
rule.message: Possible unsafe assignment to a non-final static field in a constructor.
rule.description: Identifies a possible unsafe usage of a static field.

rule.name: MissingStaticMethodInNonInstantiatableClass
rule.message: Class cannot be instantiated and does not provide any static methods or fields
rule.description: A class that has private constructors and does not have any static methods or fields cannot be used.

rule.name: AvoidSynchronizedAtMethodLevel
rule.message: Use block level rather than method level synchronization
rule.description: Method-level synchronization can cause problems when new code is added to the method. Block-level synchronization helps to ensure that only the code that needs synchronization gets it.

rule.name: MissingBreakInSwitch
rule.message: A switch statement does not contain a break
rule.description: Switch statements without break or return statements for each case option may indicate problematic behaviour. Empty cases are ignored as these indicate an intentional fall-through.

rule.name: UseNotifyAllInsteadOfNotify
rule.message: Call Thread.notifyAll() rather than Thread.notify()
rule.description: Thread.notify() awakens a thread monitoring the object. If more than one thread is monitoring, then only one is chosen. The thread chosen is arbitrary; thus its usually safer to call notifyAll() instead.

property.name: xpath

rule.name: AvoidInstanceofChecksInCatchClause
rule.message: An instanceof check is being performed on the caught exception. Create a separate catch clause for this exception type.
rule.description: Each caught exception type should be handled in its own catch clause.

rule.name: AbstractClassWithoutAbstractMethod
rule.message: This abstract class does not have any abstract methods
rule.description: The abstract class does not contain any abstract methods. An abstract class suggests an incomplete implementation, which is to be completed by subclasses implementing the abstract methods. If the class is intended to be used as a base class only (not to be instantiated directly) a protected constructor can be provided prevent direct instantiation.

rule.name: SimplifyConditional
rule.message: No need to check for null before an instanceof
rule.description: No need to check for null before an instanceof; the instanceof keyword returns false when given a null argument.

rule.name: CompareObjectsWithEquals
rule.message: Use equals() to compare object references.
rule.description: Use equals() to compare object references; avoid comparing them with ==.

rule.name: PositionLiteralsFirstInComparisons
rule.message: Position literals first in String comparisons
rule.description: Position literals first in comparisons, if the second argument is null then NullPointerExceptions can be avoided, they will just return false.

rule.name: PositionLiteralsFirstInCaseInsensitiveComparisons
rule.message: Position literals first in String comparisons for EqualsIgnoreCase
rule.description: Position literals first in comparisons, if the second argument is null then NullPointerExceptions can be avoided, they will just return false.

rule.name: UnnecessaryLocalBeforeReturn
rule.message: Consider simply returning the value vs storing it in local variable ''{0}''
rule.description: Avoid the creation of unnecessary local variables

rule.name: NonThreadSafeSingleton
rule.message: Singleton is not thread safe
rule.description:
Non-thread safe singletons can result in bad state changes. Eliminate static singletons if possible by instantiating the object directly. Static singletons are usually not needed as only a single instance exists anyway. Other possible fixes are to synchronize the entire method or to use an initialize-on-demand holder class (do not use the double-check idiom).
See Effective Java, item 48.

rule.name: SingleMethodSingleton
rule.message: Class contains multiple getInstance methods. Please review.
rule.description: Some classes contain overloaded getInstance. The problem with overloaded getInstance methods is that the instance created using the overloaded method is not cached and so, for each call and new objects will be created for every invocation.

rule.name: SingletonClassReturningNewInstance
rule.message: getInstance method always creates a new object and hence does not comply to Singleton Design Pattern behaviour. Please review
rule.description: Some classes contain overloaded getInstance. The problem with overloaded getInstance methods is that the instance created using the overloaded method is not cached and so, for each call and new objects will be created for every invocation.

rule.name: UncommentedEmptyMethodBody
rule.message: Document empty method body
rule.description: Uncommented Empty Method Body finds instances where a method body does not contain statements, but there is no comment. By explicitly commenting empty method bodies it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty methods.
rule.example: public void doSomething() { }

rule.name: UncommentedEmptyConstructor
rule.message: Document empty constructor
rule.description: Uncommented Empty Constructor finds instances where a constructor does not contain statements, but there is no comment. By explicitly commenting empty constructors it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty constructors.

property.name: ignoreExplicitConstructorInvocation
property.description: Ignore explicit constructor invocation when deciding whether constructor is empty or not

rule.name: AvoidConstantsInterface
rule.message: An Interface should be used only to model a behaviour; consider converting this to a class.
rule.description: An interface should be used only to characterize the external behaviour of an implementing class: using an interface as a container of constants is a poor usage pattern and not recommended.

rule.name: UnsynchronizedStaticDateFormatter
rule.message: Static DateFormatter objects should be accessed in a synchronized manner
rule.description: SimpleDateFormat instances are not synchronized. Sun recommends using separate format instances for each thread. If multiple threads must access a static formatter, the formatter must be synchronized either on method or block level.

rule.name: PreserveStackTrace
rule.message: New exception is thrown in catch block, original stack trace may be lost
rule.description: Throwing a new exception from a catch block without passing the original exception into the new exception will cause the original stack trace to be lost making it difficult to debug effectively.

rule.name: UseCollectionIsEmpty
rule.message: Substitute calls to size() == 0 (or size() != 0, size() > 0, size() < 1) with calls to isEmpty()
rule.description: The isEmpty() method on java.util.Collection is provided to determine if a collection has any elements. Comparing the value of size() to 0 does not convey intent as well as the isEmpty() method.

rule.name: ClassWithOnlyPrivateConstructorsShouldBeFinal
rule.message: A class which only has private constructors should be final
rule.description: A class with only private constructors should be final, unless the private constructor is invoked by a inner class.

rule.name: EmptyMethodInAbstractClassShouldBeAbstract
rule.message: An empty method in an abstract class should be abstract instead
rule.description: Empty or auto-generated methods in an abstract class should be tagged as abstract. This helps to remove their inapproprate usage by developers who should be implementing their own versions in the concrete subclasses.

property.value: //ClassOrInterfaceDeclaration[@Abstract = 'true'] /ClassOrInterfaceBody /ClassOrInterfaceBodyDeclaration /MethodDeclaration[@Abstract = 'false' and @Native = 'false'] [ ( boolean(./Block[count(./BlockStatement) = 1]/BlockStatement/Statement/ReturnStatement/Expression/PrimaryExpression/PrimaryPrefix/Literal/NullLiteral) = 'true' ) or ( boolean(./Block[count(./BlockStatement) = 1]/BlockStatement/Statement/ReturnStatement/Expression/PrimaryExpression/PrimaryPrefix/Literal[@Image = '0']) = 'true' ) or ( boolean(./Block[count(./BlockStatement) = 1]/BlockStatement/Statement/ReturnStatement/Expression/PrimaryExpression/PrimaryPrefix/Literal[string-length(@Image) = 2]) = 'true' ) or (./Block[count(./BlockStatement) = 1]/BlockStatement/Statement/EmptyStatement) or ( count (./Block/*) = 0 ) ]

rule.name: SingularField
rule.message: Perhaps ''{0}'' could be replaced by a local variable.
rule.description: Fields whose scopes are limited to just single methods do not rely on the containing object to provide them to other methods. They may be better implemented as local variables within those methods.

rule.name: ReturnEmptyArrayRatherThanNull
rule.message: Return an empty array rather than 'null'.
rule.description: For any method that returns an array, it is a better to return an empty array rather than a null reference. This removes the need for null checking all results and avoids inadvertent NullPointerExceptions.

rule.name: AbstractClassWithoutAnyMethod
rule.message: No abstract method which means that the keyword is most likely used to prevent instantiation. Use a private or protected constructor instead.
rule.description: If an abstract class does not provides any methods, it may be acting as a simple data container that is not meant to be instantiated. In this case, it is probably better to use a private or protected constructor in order to prevent instantiation than make the class misleadingly abstract.

rule.name: TooFewBranchesForASwitchStatement
rule.message: A switch with less than three branches is inefficient, use a 'if statement' instead.
rule.description: Switch statements are indended to be used to support complex branching behaviour. Using a switch for only a few cases is ill-advised, since switches are not as easy to understand as if-then statements. In these cases use the if-then statement to increase code readability.

property.name: minimumNumberCaseForASwitch
property.description: Minimum number of branches for a switch

rule.name: LogicInversion
rule.message: Use opposite operator instead of the logic complement operator.
rule.description: Use opposite operator instead of negating the whole expression with a logic complement operator.

rule.name: UseVarargs
rule.message: Consider using varargs for methods or constructors which take an array the last parameter.
rule.description: Java 5 introduced the varargs parameter declaration for methods and constructors. This syntactic sugar provides flexibility for users of these methods and constructors, allowing them to avoid having to deal with the creation of an array.

rule.name: FieldDeclarationsShouldBeAtStartOfClass
rule.message: Fields should be declared at the top of the class, before any method declarations, constructors, initializers or inner classes.
rule.description: Fields should be declared at the top of the class, before any method declarations, constructors, initializers or inner classes.

rule.name: GodClass
rule.message: Possible God class
rule.description: The God Class rule detects the God Class design flaw using metrics. God classes do too many things, are very big and overly complex. They should be split apart to be more object-oriented. The rule uses the detection strategy described in "Object-Oriented Metrics in Practice". The violations are reported against the entire class. See also the references: Michele Lanza and Radu Marinescu. Object-Oriented Metrics in Practice: Using Software Metrics to Characterize, Evaluate, and Improve the Design of Object-Oriented Systems. Springer, Berlin, 1 edition, October 2006. Page 80.

rule.name: AvoidProtectedMethodInFinalClassNotExtending
rule.message: Avoid protected methods in a final class that doesn't extend anything other than Object. Change to private or package access.
rule.description: Do not use protected methods in most final classes since they cannot be subclassed. This should only be allowed in final classes that extend other classes with protected methods (whose visibility cannot be reduced). Clarify your intent by using private or package access modifiers instead.

rule.name: ConstantsInInterface
rule.message: Avoid constants in interfaces. Interfaces define types, constants are implementation details better placed in classes or enums. See Effective Java, item 19.
rule.description: Avoid constants in interfaces. Interfaces should define types, constants are implementation details better placed in classes or enums. See Effective Java, item 19.

property.name: ignoreIfHasMethods
property.description: Whether to ignore constants in interfaces if the interface defines any methods
